header.title: Les Admirables Secrets D'Albert Le Grand
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire, Natural Magic, Medical Astrology, Folk Medicine, Physiognomy, Alchemy

central_thesis: This work, attributed to Albertus Magnus, synthesizes Aristotelian natural philosophy, medical astrology, and popular superstitions into a practical guide of 'admirable secrets.' It aims to provide knowledge concerning human generation (especially women's physiology and reproductive matters), the inherent 'virtues' of natural substances (herbs, stones, animal parts), and metallurgical processes, all framed as a system for health, utility, and influencing natural phenomena. The book also includes a detailed treatise on physiognomy and a system for determining auspicious and inauspicious days.

structure_content.chapter_title: LIVRE PREMIER: SECRETS DES FEMMES ET DE LA GÉNÉRATION
structure_content.summary: Focuses on human reproduction and female physiology, discussing embryo generation, conception, menstruation, sperm, fetal development, and the astrological influences on the fetus. It also includes methods to determine conception signs, gender, and virginity, alongside controversial views on women's bodily functions and remedies for reproductive issues.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE I: De la génération de l'Embrion, & de quelle maniere l'homme eſt engendré. Comment ſe fait la Conception , & ce que c'eſt que les Menſtrues & le Sperme, &c.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the process of embryo generation, human procreation, conception, and the roles of menstruation and sperm.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE II: De quelle maniere ſe forme le Foetus: Influences des Puiſſances Céleſtes ſur le Foetus , &c.
structure_content.summary: Explains fetal development and the celestial influences (astrology) on the fetus.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE III: Des Influences des Planetes. De quelle maniere elles agiſſent ſur les corps.
structure_content.summary: Detailed exploration of planetary influences on the human body, providing a basis for medical astrology.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE IV: Comment s'engendrent les Animaux imparfaits. Les effets admirables des cheveux d'une Femme. Diverſité des Animaux, & d'où elle vient.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the generation of imperfect animals, peculiar effects of women's hair, and animal diversity, often linking these to natural magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE V: De la ſortie du Foetus. Raiſon pourquoi les Femmes accouchent dans le ſixieme mois, & pourquoi l'une ſouffre plus que l'autre dans l'accouchements, &c.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VI: D'un Monſtre de Nature, & comme il ſe forme.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VII: Des ſignes de la Conception, &c.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE VIII: Des marques pour connoître ſi une Femme eſt enceinte d'un Garçon ou d'une Fille.
structure_content.summary: Methods to determine the sex of an unborn child.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE IX: La maniere de connoître quand une Fille a perdu ſa Virginité, &c.
structure_content.summary: Techniques to ascertain a woman's virginity.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE X: Des signes de la Chaſteté; & le venin que les vieilles Femmes communiquent aux Enfants par leurs regards, &c.
structure_content.summary: Describes signs of chastity and the supposed 'venomous' influence of old women's gaze on children, reflecting prevalent superstitions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPITRE XI: Du défaut de la Matrice, & une Hiſtoire que Galien raconte d'une femme ſuffo-quée par la Matrice, &c.
structure_content.summary: Discusses uterine issues and a case study from Galen about 'suffocation of the matrix'.

structure_content.chapter_title: LIVRE QUATRIEME: TRAITÉ DE LA PHYSIONOMIE
structure_content.summary: Provides a comprehensive guide to physiognomy, correlating physical attributes (from hair to feet) with character and inclinations. It also delves into folk astrology ('happy' and 'unhappy' days), and various medical remedies for fevers, plague, and other ailments, alongside lifestyle advice and practices like bloodletting.

key_concepts.definition: The intrinsic, often hidden, powers and properties possessed by natural objects (herbs, stones, animal parts, bodily fluids) that can be manipulated for specific effects through natural magic.

The astrological concept that planetary positions and zodiacal signs exert specific, predictable forces upon terrestrial phenomena, human temperament, health, and the optimal timing of magical/medical operations.
The underlying magical law, often unstated but evident, that 'like affects like' or that things once in contact continue to influence each other, forming the basis for many practical applications.

The art and 'science' of discerning an individual's character, temperament, and potential destiny by analyzing their physical appearance, especially facial features and various bodily characteristics.

A core philosophical concept, largely derived from Aristotle, explaining the processes of creation, development, decay, and transformation in both living beings and inanimate matter, particularly as applied to human and animal reproduction.

A calendrical system, based on lunar and planetary cycles, used to predict the fortunate or unfortunate nature of specific days for various undertakings, medical treatments, or events in one's life history.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a system of natural magic and applied occultism, where the inherent 'virtues' of various natural elements—herbs, stones, animal parts, and bodily excretions—are harnessed for specific, practical purposes. This system is interwoven with a form of medical astrology, utilizing planetary and zodiacal influences to determine optimal timings for preparations and applications. It encompasses remedies for diseases, methods to influence human generation (including sex determination and conception), and rudimentary metallurgical and alchemical processes. The core mechanism is sympathetic action, where prepared substances or timed operations are believed to directly affect a desired outcome.
tools: Natural substances: diverse herbs (many named), precious and common stones, various animal parts (feathers, bones, brains, internal organs, blood), and human/animal bodily fluids and excrements (urine, saliva, droppings).
Basic laboratory implements for mixing, crushing, heating, and application (e.g., mortars, alembics, ovens).
Astrological tables (like the 'Table des Astres & des Planetes' on page 112) for timing operations.
For metallurgy: specific chemicals, heat sources, and other substances to alter metal properties.
rituals: Operations are presented as 'secrets' or 'recipes,' which are essentially practical instructions. These often involve gathering specific ingredients (e.g., particular animal droppings, certain herbs), performing precise preparations (e.g., pulverizing, mixing, applying as a poultice, consuming as a drink), and executing these actions at astrologically determined 'planetary hours' for maximum efficacy. While not complex ceremonial magic, the precise instructions and timing constitute a form of ritualized practice.
Utilizing specific calendrical systems to determine 'happy' or 'unhappy' days for commencing undertakings or predicting outcomes, based on lunar and planetary cycles.

critical_analysis.relevance: This grimoire is a crucial historical artifact for understanding popular Western esotericism and natural magic from the early modern period. It demonstrates the synthesis of Aristotelian thought, Galenic medicine, astrological timing, and widespread folk beliefs regarding health, reproduction, and the occult properties of nature. Despite its problematic views on women and lack of modern scientific rigor, it illuminates the intellectual and practical landscape of its time, showcasing the blend of genuine inquiry, superstition, and attempts at systematic knowledge. Its inclusion of metallurgical 'secrets' also links it to rudimentary alchemy.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The text was intended for 'curious' individuals, scholars, and practitioners (both medical and magical) seeking to understand and manipulate natural forces. Its practical focus on remedies, conception, and material transformations suggests utility for a wide, albeit specialized, audience. The compiler's warning against 'young people' and 'small minds' implies the content's perceived esoteric or controversial nature, likely due to its frank discussion of sexuality and reliance on non-Christian interpretations of natural phenomena, despite the Christian framing.
